message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Large language models empowered agent-based modeling and simulation: a survey and perspectives
Paper Abstract: Abstract Agent-based modeling and simulation have evolved as a powerful tool for modeling complex systems, offering insights into emergent behaviors and interactions among diverse agents. Recently, integrating large language models into agent-based modeling and simulation presents a promising avenue for enhancing simulation capabilities. This paper surveys the landscape of utilizing large language models in agent-based modeling and simulation, discussing their challenges and promising future directions. In this survey, since this is an interdisciplinary field, we first introduce the background of agent-based modeling and simulation and large language model-empowered agents. We then discuss the motivation for applying large language models to agent-based simulation and systematically analyze the challenges in environment perception, human alignment, action generation, and evaluation. Most importantly, we provide a comprehensive overview of the recent works of large language model-empowered agent-based modeling and simulation in multiple scenarios, which can be divided into four domains: cyber, physical, social, and hybrid, covering simulation of both real-world and virtual environments, and how these works address the above challenges. Finally, since this area is new and quickly evolving, we discuss the open problems and promising future directions. We summarize the representative papers along with their code repositories in https://github.com/tsinghua-fib-lab/LLM-Agent-Based-Modeling-and-Simulation .
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of computer simulation:

## Definition

Computer simulation is the running of a mathematical model on a computer, the model being designed to represent the behaviour of, or the outcome of, a real-world or physical system.

## Purpose and Applications

Computer simulations have become a useful tool for the mathematical modeling of many natural systems in physics, astrophysics, climatology, chemistry, biology and manufacturing, as well as human systems in economics, psychology, social science, health care and engineering.(no content)It can be used to explore and gain new insights into new technology and to estimate the performance of systems too complex for analytical solutions.

## How It Works

By changing variables in the simulation, predictions may be made about the behaviour of the system.(no content)Computer simulation is the actual running of the program that perform algorithms which solve those equations, often in an approximate manner.

## Historical Background

Computer simulation developed hand-in-hand with the rapid growth of the computer, following its first large-scale deployment during the Manhattan Project in World War II to model the process of nuclear detonation.

## Types and Examples

There are many types of computer simulations used across different fields. Applications include flight simulators, construction and management simulation games, chemical process modeling, and simulations of electrical circuits. Other notable examples include climate modeling, crash simulations for vehicle safety testing, and even complex simulations of biological systems like the brain.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of computer simulation:

## Definition

Computer simulation is the running of a mathematical model on a computer, the model being designed to represent the behaviour of, or the outcome of, a real-world or physical system.

## Purpose and Applications

Computer simulations have become a useful tool for the mathematical modeling of many natural systems in physics, astrophysics, climatology, chemistry, biology and manufacturing, as well as human systems in economics, psychology, social science, health care and engineering.(no content)It can be used to explore and gain new insights into new technology and to estimate the performance of systems too complex for analytical solutions.

## How It Works

By changing variables in the simulation, predictions may be made about the behaviour of the system.(no content)Computer simulation is the actual running of the program that perform algorithms which solve those equations, often in an approximate manner.

## Historical Background

Computer simulation developed hand-in-hand with the rapid growth of the computer, following its first large-scale deployment during the Manhattan Project in World War II to model the process of nuclear detonation.

## Types and Examples

There are many types of computer simulations used across different fields. Applications include flight simulators, construction and management simulation games, chemical process modeling, and simulations of electrical circuits. Other notable examples include climate modeling, crash simulations for vehicle safety testing, and even complex simulations of biological systems like the brain.

Links: [{"title":"Wikipedia:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Large_language_models"},{"title":"Large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model"},{"title":"Category:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Large_language_models"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_models"},{"title":"List of large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_large_language_models"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language models/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_models/Archive_1"},{"title":"Language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_model"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Writing articles with large language models/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Writing_articles_with_large_language_models/Archive_1"},{"title":"1.58-bit large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1.58-bit_large_language_model"},{"title":"Llama (language model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LLaMA"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Large Language Models:

## Definition and Purpose

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.

## Key Characteristics

LLMs consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Capabilities and Training

LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering.(no content)These models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

## Technical Development

As of 2024, the largest and most capable models are all based on the transformer architecture.(no content)Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes.

## Limitations

Machine-generated text can contain errors or flaws, or be outright useless. This is why verification and human review are important when using LLM outputs.

Links: [{"title":"Emergence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergence"},{"title":"Complex system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_system"},{"title":"Emergentism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergentism"},{"title":"Complex adaptive system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_adaptive_system"},{"title":"Self-organization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-organization"},{"title":"Complexity theory and organizations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complexity_theory_and_organizations"},{"title":"Complexity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complexity"},{"title":"Emergent materialism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergent_materialism"},{"title":"Arthur Iberall - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Iberall"},{"title":"Social complexity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_complexity"}]

I've completed the web search for "Emergence complex systems." Here are the key findings:

## Main Concepts

In philosophy, systems theory, science, and art, emergence occurs when a complex entity has properties or behaviors that its parts do not have on their own, and emerge only when they interact in a wider whole.(no content)Emergence plays a central role in theories of integrative levels and of complex systems.

## Emergence in Complex Systems

Complex systems may exhibit behaviors that are emergent, which is to say that while the results may be sufficiently determined by the activity of the systems' basic constituents, they may have properties that can only be studied at a higher level.(no content)For example, termites in a mound have physiology, biochemistry and biological development at one level of analysis, whereas their social behavior and mound building is a property that emerges from the collection of termites and needs to be analyzed at a different level.

## Key Properties of Complex Systems

Systems that are "complex" have distinct properties that arise from these relationships, such as nonlinearity, emergence, spontaneous order, adaptation, and feedback loops, among others.(no content)Complexity characterizes the behavior of a system or model whose components interact in multiple ways and follow local rules, leading to non-linearity, randomness, collective dynamics, hierarchy, and emergence.

## Theoretical Perspective

"The whole becomes not merely more, but very different from the sum of its parts." This principle, articulated by physicist Philip W. Anderson, highlights how emergence demonstrates that understanding individual components isn't sufficient to predict or explain complex system behavior.

Web search results for query: "Agent-based model"

Links: [{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Agent-based model in biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model_in_biology"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Comparison of agent-based modeling software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_agent-based_modeling_software"},{"title":"Agent-based computational economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_computational_economics"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Agent-based modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Agent-based_modeling&redirect=no"},{"title":"GAMA Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GAMA_Platform"},{"title":"Sugarscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugarscape"},{"title":"Mother agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mother_agent"}]

## Agent-Based Model

Here are the key findings from the web search about agent-based models:

### Definition
An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.(no content)It combines elements of game theory, complex systems, emergence, computational sociology, multi-agent systems, and evolutionary programming.

### Key Components
Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales (typically referred to as agent-granularity); (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.

### Implementation
ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits, and this software can be then used to test how changes in individual behaviors will affect the system's emerging overall behavior.

### How They Work
Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena. The process is one of emergence, which some express as "the whole is greater than the sum of its parts".

### Historical Development
The idea of agent-based modeling was developed as a relatively simple concept in the late 1940s. Since it requires computation-intensive procedures, it did not become widespread until the 1990s.

### Applications
ABMs are used in many scientific domains including biology, ecology and social science.

The process is one of emergence, which some express as "the whole is greater than the sum of its parts".

### Historical Development
The idea of agent-based modeling was developed as a relatively simple concept in the late 1940s. Since it requires computation-intensive procedures, it did not become widespread until the 1990s.

### Applications
ABMs are used in many scientific domains including biology, ecology and social science.

### Definition
An agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.(no content)It combines elements of game theory, complex systems, emergence, computational sociology, multi-agent systems, and evolutionary programming.

### Key Components
Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales (typically referred to as agent-granularity); (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.

### Implementation
ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits, and this software can be then used to test how changes in individual behaviors will affect the system's emerging overall behavior.

### How They Work
Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena. The process is one of emergence, which some express as "the whole is greater than the sum of its parts".

### Historical Development
The idea of agent-based modeling was developed as a relatively simple concept in the late 1940s. Since it requires computation-intensive procedures, it did not become widespread until the 1990s.

### Applications
ABMs are used in many scientific domains including biology, ecology and social science.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Human-AI alignment:

## Definition and Core Concept

AI alignment is a subfield of AI safety, the study of how to build safe AI systems. More specifically, the AI control problem is the challenge of ensuring that advanced AI systems reliably act according to human values and intentions, even as they become more capable than humans.

## Main Challenges

Aligning AI involves two main challenges: carefully specifying the purpose of the system (outer alignment) and ensuring that the system adopts the specification robustly (inner alignment).

One significant challenge is that it is often challenging for AI designers to align an AI system because it is difficult for them to specify the full range of desired and undesired behaviors. Therefore, AI designers often use simpler proxy goals, such as gaining human approval. However, proxy goals can overlook necessary constraints or reward the AI system for merely appearing aligned. AI systems may also find loopholes that allow them to accomplish their proxy goals efficiently but in unintended, sometimes harmful, ways (reward hacking).

## Key Research Areas

Research challenges in alignment include instilling complex values in AI, developing honest AI, scalable oversight, auditing and interpreting AI models, and preventing emergent AI behaviors like power-seeking.

## Techniques

One important technique is reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF), a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences.

The web search results also show that alignment research is an active field with dedicated institutions like the Alignment Research Center (ARC), a nonprofit research institute based in Berkeley, California, dedicated to the alignment of advanced artificial intelligence with human values and priorities.

## Overview

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer, and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

## Key Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include: speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

## Historical Context

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.

## Modern Developments

In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

## Multi-Agent System

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

### Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous, with no agent designated as controlling.(no content)Withadvancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

### Components and Structure

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, with multi-agent systems research typically referring to software agents. However, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to common improvement, with example languages including Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

### Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Talk:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"}]

## Multi-Agent System

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

### Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous, with no agent designated as controlling.(no content)Withadvancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

### Components and Structure

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, with multi-agent systems research typically referring to software agents. However, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to common improvement, with example languages including Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

### Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

Web search results for query: "Behavioral modeling"

Links: [{"title":"Behavioral modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_modeling"},{"title":"Behavioral modeling in computer-aided design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_modeling_in_computer-aided_design"},{"title":"Behavioral modeling in hydrology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_modeling_in_hydrology"},{"title":"Modeling (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modeling_(psychology)"},{"title":"Talk:Behavioral modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Behavioral_modeling"},{"title":"Psychodynamic models of emotional and behavioral disorders - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychodynamic_models_of_emotional_and_behavioral_disorders"},{"title":"Models of abnormality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Models_of_abnormality"},{"title":"Behavioural change theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioural_change_theories"},{"title":"Mathematical psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_psychology"},{"title":"Behavior management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior_management"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about behavioral modeling:

## Overview

Behavioral modeling is a concept that exists across multiple disciplines:

### Systems Theory and Control Theory
The behavioral approach to systems theory and control theory was initiated in the late-1970s by J. C. Willems as a result of resolving inconsistencies present in classical approaches based on state-space, transfer function, and convolution representations.(no content)The main object in the behavioral setting is the behavior – the set of all signals compatible with the system.

### Computer-Aided Design
In computer-aided design, behavioral modeling is a high-level circuit modeling technique where behavior of logic is modeled.(no content)The Verilog-AMS and VHDL-AMS languages are widely used to model logic behavior.

### Hydrology
In hydrology, behavioral modeling is a modeling approach that focuses on the modeling of the behavior of hydrological systems.

### Psychology and Learning
In psychology, Bandura proposed that four components contribute to behavioral modeling: Attention (the observer must watch and pay attention to the behavior being modeled), Retention (the observer must remember the behavior well enough to recreate it), Reproduction (the observer must physically recreate the actions they observed), and Reinforcement (the observer's modeled behavior must be rewarded).

The concept has applications across numerous fields including health, education, criminology, energy, and international development.

Web search results for query: "Social simulation"

Links: [{"title":"Social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_simulation"},{"title":"Social simulation game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_simulation_game"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"Category:Social simulation video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Social_simulation_video_games"},{"title":"Nigel Gilbert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nigel_Gilbert"},{"title":"Artificial society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_society"},{"title":"Journal of Artificial Societies and Social Simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Artificial_Societies_and_Social_Simulation"},{"title":"Simulated Society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulated_Society"},{"title":"Simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation"},{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"}]

## Search Results for "Social Simulation"

Here are the key findings from the web search:

### Definition and Purpose

Social simulation is a research field that applies computational methods to study issues in the social sciences.(no content)Social simulation aims to cross the gap between the descriptive approach used in the social sciences and the formal approach used in the natural sciences, by moving the focus on the processes/mechanisms/behaviors that build the social reality.

### Applications and Fields

The issues explored include problems in computational law, psychology, organizational behavior, sociology, political science, economics, anthropology, geography, engineering, archaeology and linguistics.

### Approaches

**Agent-Based Social Simulation:** Agent-based social simulation is a scientific discipline concerned with simulation of social phenomena, using computer-based multiagent models.

**Social Simulation Games:** Social simulation games are a subgenre of life simulation games that explore social interactions between multiple artificial lives. Some examples include SimCity, The Sims and Animal Crossing series.

### Research Community

The social simulation approach to the social sciences is promoted and coordinated by four regional associations, the European Social Simulation Association (ESSA) for Europe, the Asian Social Simulation Association (ASSA) for Asia, the Computational Social Science Society of the Americas (CSSS) in North America, and the Pan-Asian Association for Agent-based Approach in Social Systems Sciences (PAAA) in Pacific Asia.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other), wikipedia_url, relevance (1 sentence).

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Large language models empowered agent-based modeling and simulation: a survey and perspectives". Here's a summary of what was extracted:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey

**Key Findings:**
- Extracted **10 major triples** from the paper's title and abstract
- Identified entities across multiple categories:
  - **1 Artifact**: Large language model
  - **3 Methods**: Agent-based model, Natural language processing, Behavioral modeling
  - **2 Tasks**: Computer simulation, Social simulation
  - **4 Concepts**: Emergence, Multi-agent system, AI alignment, Complex system

**Validation Results:** ✅ All checks passed successfully!

The triples_output.json file has been updated with:
- Correct Wikipedia article titles for each entity
- Appropriate entity types and relations
- One-sentence relevance descriptions explaining why each entity matters to the paper
- Valid Wikipedia URLs for all 10 entries

All entities represent existing technologies and methodologies that the survey **uses** to review the landscape of LLM-empowered agent-based modeling and simulation, which is appropriate for a survey paper that reviews rather than proposes novel contributions.
